title: Steve Bates
text:
Steve Bates (born 4 March 1963) is a rugby coach and retired from former <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player. He played at <a href="Scrum-half%20%28rugby%20union%29">scrum-half</a> for <a href="Wasps%20RFC">London Wasps</a> and was capped once for the <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England national rugby union team</a>. He twice worked as a coach at <a href="Newcastle%20Falcons">Newcastle Falcons</a>, 1995–2003 and 2007–2010.
Early life.
Steven Michael Bates was born on 4 March 1963 in <a href="Merthyr%20Tydfil">Merthyr Tydfil</a>, Wales. During his days as a player, in the amateur era, Bates was a schoolteacher at <a href="Radley%20College">Radley College</a> and <a href="Lord%20Wandsworth%20College">Lord Wandsworth College</a> in Hampshire.
Rugby career.
He played at scrum-half for London Wasps, where he formed a successful partnership with <a href="Fly-half%20%28rugby%20union%29">fly-half</a> <a href="Rob%20Andrew">Rob Andrew</a>. He was capped once for England, against in <a href="Bucharest">Bucharest</a> in 1989, and was on <a href="1994%20England%20rugby%20union%20tour%20of%20South%20Africa">England's tour of South Africa in 1994</a>.
In 1995, when Andrew left Wasps to become Director of Rugby at <a href="Newcastle%20Falcons">Newcastle Falcons</a>, Bates followed him, becoming the Falcons' head coach. Bates was instrumental in attracting the fly-half <a href="Jonny%20Wilkinson">Jonny Wilkinson</a> to Newcastle in the summer of 1997, with Wilkinson having previously been a pupil at Lord Wandsworth College where Bates taught. Under Bates, Newcastle were promoted to the <a href="Guinness%20Premiership">Premiership</a> at the end of the 1996–97 season and went on to top the league at the first attempt, in 1997–98; they reached the final of the <a href="Tetley%27s%20Bitter%20Cup">Tetley's Bitter Cup</a> in 1999 and won the trophy (by then known as the <a href="Powergen%20Cup">Powergen Cup</a> in 2001. Bates left Newcastle in March 2003
In 2004 Bates was appointed as head coach of <a href="Border%20Reivers%20%28rugby%29">Border Reivers</a>, taking over from New Zealander Tony Gilbert, who was returning home. Bates successfully guided Borders back into the Heineken Cup in 2006–07 and, during his time with the club, also coached Scotland A to the final of the <a href="2006%20Churchill%20Cup">2006 Churchill Cup</a>, which they lost to the <a href="New%20Zealand%20M%C4%81ori%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand Māori</a>, after wins against <a href="England%20Saxons">England Saxons</a> and .
When the Scottish Rugby Union announced that Border Reivers were to be disbanded at the end of the 2006–07 season, Bates was headhunted by Newcastle Falcons to become their Coaching and Technical Director and rejoined the club in June 2007. Bates was sacked by the Falcons in May 2010.
In January 2008, the <a href="Rugby%20Football%20Union">Rugby Football Union</a> announced the appointment of Bates as head coach of <a href="England%20Saxons">England Saxons</a> on a part-time basis.
In 2011 Bates was appointed the director of sport at <a href="Fettes%20College">Fettes College</a> in Edinburgh. Bates left to become head coach of England Rugby Union Under 20s in March 2017.
Personal life.
Bates is married with two children, Lottie and Emma.
